column2: CHAPTER XXXII
column3: CHAPTER thirty two

column2: The winter passed and the spring came.
column3: The winter passed and the spring came.

column2: The Mill House, even to the most skeptical observer, showed signs of being a success.
column3: The Mill House, even to the most skeptical observer, showed signs of being a success.

column2: Even already a visible influence had radiated from its shining windows and orderly yard; and the neighboring houses, with their obvious attempt at "slickin' up," reminded one of a small boy who has been told to wash his face, for company was coming.
column3: Even already a visible influence had radiated from its shining windows and orderly yard; and the neighboring houses, with their obvious attempt at "slickin' up," reminded one of a small boy who has been told to wash his face, for company was coming.

column2: The classes boasted a larger attendance, and the stomachs and the babies of many a family in the town were feeling the beneficial results of the lessons.
column3: The classes boasted a larger attendance, and the stomachs and the babies of many a family in the town were feeling the beneficial results of the lessons.

column2: To Margaret, however, the whole thing seemed hopelessly small: there was so much to do, so little done!
column3: To Margaret, however, the whole thing seemed hopelessly small: there was so much to do, so little done!

column2: She was still the little girl with the teaspoon and the bowl of sand; and the chasm yawned as wide as ever.
column3: She was still the little girl with the teaspoon and the bowl of sand; and the chasm yawned as wide as ever.

column2: To tell the truth, Margaret was tired, discouraged, and homesick.
column3: To tell the truth, Margaret was tired, discouraged, and homesick.

column2: For months her strength, time, nerves, and sympathies had been taxed to the utmost; and now that there had come a breathing space, when the intricate machinery of her scheme could run for a moment without her hand at the throttle, she was left weak and nerveless.
column3: For months her strength, time, nerves, and sympathies had been taxed to the utmost; and now that there had come a breathing space, when the intricate machinery of her scheme could run for a moment without her hand at the throttle, she was left weak and nerveless.

column2: She was, in fact, perilously near a breakdown.
column3: She was, in fact, perilously near a breakdown.

column2: Added to all this, she was lonely.
column3: Added to all this, she was lonely.

column2: More than she would own to herself she missed her friends, her home life at Hilcrest, and the tender care and sympathetic interest that had been lavished upon her for so many years.
column3: More than she would own to herself she missed her friends, her home life at Hilcrest, and the tender care and sympathetic interest that had been lavished upon her for so many years.

column2: Here she was the head, the strong tower of defense, the one to whom everybody came with troubles, perplexities, and griefs.
column3: Here she was the head, the strong tower of defense, the one to whom everybody came with troubles, perplexities, and griefs.

column2: There was no human being to whom she could turn for comfort.
column3: There was no human being to whom she could turn for comfort.

column2: They all looked to her.
column3: They all looked to her.

column2: Even Bobby McGinnis, when she saw him at all--which was seldom--treated her with a frigid deference that was inexpressibly annoying to her.
column3: Even Bobby McGinnis, when she saw him at all-which was seldom-treated her with a frigid deference that was inexpressibly annoying to her.

column2: From the Spencers she heard irregularly.
column3: From the Spencers she heard irregularly.

column2: Earlier in the winter the letters had been more frequent: nervously anxious epistles of some length from Mrs. Merideth; stilted notes, half protesting, half pleading, from Ned; and short, but wonderfully sympathetic communications from Frank.
column3: Earlier in the winter the letters had been more frequent: nervously anxious epistles of some length from mrs Merideth; stilted notes, half protesting, half pleading, from Ned; and short, but wonderfully sympathetic communications from Frank.

column2: Later Frank had fallen very ill with a fever of some sort, and Mrs. Merideth and Ned had written only hurried little bulletins from the sick-room.
column3: Later Frank had fallen very ill with a fever of some sort, and mrs Merideth and Ned had written only hurried little bulletins from the sick room.

column2: Then had come the good news that Frank was out of danger, though still far too weak to undertake the long journey home.
column3: Then had come the good news that Frank was out of danger, though still far too weak to undertake the long journey home.

column2: Their letters showed unmistakably their impatience at the delay, and questioned her as to her health and welfare, but could set no date for their return.
column3: Their letters showed unmistakably their impatience at the delay, and questioned her as to her health and welfare, but could set no date for their return.

column2: Frank, in particular, was disturbed, they said.
column3: Frank, in particular, was disturbed, they said.

column2: He had not planned to leave either herself or the mills so long, it being his intention when he went away merely to take a short trip with his sister and brother, and then hurry back to America alone.
column3: He had not planned to leave either herself or the mills so long, it being his intention when he went away merely to take a short trip with his sister and brother, and then hurry back to America alone.

column2: As for Frank himself--he had not written her since his illness.
column3: As for Frank himself-he had not written her since his illness.

column2: Margaret was thinking of all this, and was feeling specially forlorn as she sat alone in the little sitting-room at the Mill House one evening in early April.
column3: Margaret was thinking of all this, and was feeling specially forlorn as she sat alone in the little sitting room at the Mill House one evening in early April.

column2: She held a book before her, but she was not reading; and she looked up at once when Patty entered the room.
column3: She held a book before her, but she was not reading; and she looked up at once when Patty entered the room.

column2: I'm sorry ter trouble ye, began Patty, hesitatingly, "but Bobby McGinnis is here an' wanted me ter ask ye----"
column3: I'm sorry ter trouble ye, began Patty, hesitatingly, "but Bobby McGinnis is here an' wanted me ter ask ye----"

column2: Margaret raised an imperious hand.
column3: Margaret raised an imperious hand.

column2: That's all right, Patty, she said so sharply that Patty opened wide her eyes; "but suppose you just ask Bobby McGinnis to come here to me and ask his question direct.
column3: That's all right, Patty, she said so sharply that Patty opened wide her eyes; "but suppose you just ask Bobby McGinnis to come here to me and ask his question direct.

column2: I will see him now." And Patty, wondering vaguely what had come to her gentle-eyed, gentle-voiced mistress--as she insisted upon calling Margaret--fled precipitately.
column3: I will see him now." And Patty, wondering vaguely what had come to her gentle eyed, gentle voiced mistress-as she insisted upon calling Margaret-fled precipitately.

column2: Two minutes later Bobby McGinnis himself stood tall and straight just inside the door.
column3: Two minutes later Bobby McGinnis himself stood tall and straight just inside the door.

column2: You sent for me? he asked.
column3: You sent for me? he asked.

column2: Margaret sprang to her feet.
column3: Margaret sprang to her feet.

column2: All the pent loneliness of the past weeks and months burst forth in a stinging whip of retort.
column3: All the pent loneliness of the past weeks and months burst forth in a stinging whip of retort.

column2: Yes, I sent for you. She paused, but the man did not speak, and in a moment she went on hurriedly, feverishly.
column3: Yes, I sent for you. She paused, but the man did not speak, and in a moment she went on hurriedly, feverishly.

column2: I always send for you--if I see you at all, and yet you know how hard I'm trying to help these people, and that you are the only one here that can help me.
column3: I always send for you-if I see you at all, and yet you know how hard I'm trying to help these people, and that you are the only one here that can help me.

column2: She paused again, and again the man was silent.
column3: She paused again, and again the man was silent.

column2: Don't you know what I'm trying to do? she asked.
column3: Don't you know what I'm trying to do? she asked.

column2: Yes. The lips closed firmly over the single word.
column3: Yes. The lips closed firmly over the single word.

column2: Didn't I ask you to help me?	Didn't I ask you to help me?
column3: true

column2: Didn't I appoint us a committee of two to do the work?" Her voice shook, and her chin trembled like that of a grieved child.
column3: Didn't I appoint us a committee of two to do the work?" Her voice shook, and her chin trembled like that of a grieved child.

column2: Yes. Again that strained, almost harsh monosyllable.
column3: Yes. Again that strained, almost harsh monosyllable.

column2: Margaret made an impatient gesture.
column3: Margaret made an impatient gesture.

column2: Bobby McGinnis, why don't you help me? she demanded, tearfully.
column3: Bobby McGinnis, why don't you help me? she demanded, tearfully.

column2: Why do you stand aloof and send to me?	Why do you stand aloof and send to me?
column3: false

column2: Why don't you come to me frankly and freely, and tell me the best way to deal with these people?"
column3: Why don't you come to me frankly and freely, and tell me the best way to deal with these people?"

column2: There was no answer.
column3: There was no answer.

column2: The man had half turned his face so that only his profile showed clean-cut and square-chinned against the close-shut door.
column3: The man had half turned his face so that only his profile showed clean cut and square chinned against the close shut door.

column2: Don't you know that I am alone here--that I have no friends but you and Patty? she went on tremulously.
column3: Don't you know that I am alone here-that I have no friends but you and Patty? she went on tremulously.

column2: Do you think it kind of you to let me struggle along alone like this?	Do you think it kind of you to let me struggle along alone like this?
column3: false

column2: Sometimes it seems almost as if you were afraid----"
column3: Sometimes it seems almost as if you were afraid----"

column2: I am afraid, cut in a voice shaken with emotion.
column3: I am afraid, cut in a voice shaken with emotion.

column2: Bobby! breathed Margaret in surprised dismay, falling back before the fire in the eyes that suddenly turned and flashed straight into hers. "Why, Bobby!"
column3: Bobby! breathed Margaret in surprised dismay, falling back before the fire in the eyes that suddenly turned and flashed straight into hers. "Why, Bobby!"

column2: If the man heard, he did not heed.
column3: If the man heard, he did not heed.

column2: The bonds of his self-control had snapped, and the torrent of words came with a force that told how great had been the pressure.
column3: The bonds of his self control had snapped, and the torrent of words came with a force that told how great had been the pressure.

column2: He had stepped forward as she fell back, and his eyes still blazed into hers.
column3: He had stepped forward as she fell back, and his eyes still blazed into hers.

column2: I _am_ afraid--I'm afraid of myself, he cried.
column3: I underscore am underscore afraid-I'm afraid of myself, he cried.

column2: I don't dare to trust myself within sight of your dear eyes, or within touch of your dear hands--though all the while I'm hungry for both.	I don't dare to trust myself within sight of your dear eyes, or within touch of your dear hands-though all the while I'm hungry for both.
column3: true

column2: Perhaps I do let you send for me, instead of coming of my own free will; but I'm never without the thought of you, and the hope of catching somewhere a glimpse of even your dress.
column3: Perhaps I do let you send for me, instead of coming of my own free will; but I'm never without the thought of you, and the hope of catching somewhere a glimpse of even your dress.

column2: Perhaps I do stand aloof; but many's the night I've walked the street outside, watching the light at your window, and many's the night I've not gone home until dawn lest some harm come to the woman I loved so--good God! what am I saying!" he broke off hoarsely, dropping his face into his hands, and sinking into the chair behind him.
column3: Perhaps I do stand aloof; but many's the night I've walked the street outside, watching the light at your window, and many's the night I've not gone home until dawn lest some harm come to the woman I loved so-good God! what am I saying!" he broke off hoarsely, dropping his face into his hands, and sinking into the chair behind him.

column2: Over by the table Margaret stood silent, motionless, her eyes on the bowed figure of the man before her.
column3: Over by the table Margaret stood silent, motionless, her eyes on the bowed figure of the man before her.

column2: Gradually her confused senses were coming into something like order.
column3: Gradually her confused senses were coming into something like order.

column2: Slowly her dazed thoughts were taking shape.
column3: Slowly her dazed thoughts were taking shape.

column2: It was her own fault.
column3: It was her own fault.

column2: She had brought this thing upon herself.
column3: She had brought this thing upon herself.

column2: She should have seen--have understood.
column3: She should have seen-have understood.

column2: And now she had caused all this sorrow to this dear friend of her childhood--the little boy who had befriended her when she was alone and hungry and lost....
column3: And now she had caused all this sorrow to this dear friend of her childhood-the little boy who had befriended her when she was alone and hungry and lost....

column2: But, after all, why should he not love her?
column3: But, after all, why should he not love her?

column2: And why should she not--love him?
column3: And why should she not-love him?

column2: He was good and true and noble, and for years he had loved her--she remembered now their childish compact, and she bitterly reproached herself for not thinking of it before--it might have saved her this....
column3: He was good and true and noble, and for years he had loved her-she remembered now their childish compact, and she bitterly reproached herself for not thinking of it before-it might have saved her this....

column2: Still, did she want to save herself this?
column3: Still, did she want to save herself this?

column2: Was it not, after all, the very best thing that could have happened?
column3: Was it not, after all, the very best thing that could have happened?

column2: Where, and how could she do more good in the world than right here with this strong, loving heart to help her?...
column3: Where, and how could she do more good in the world than right here with this strong, loving heart to help her?...

column2: She loved him, too--she was sure she did--though she had never realized it before. Doubtless that was half the cause of her present restlessness and unhappiness--she had loved him all the time, and did not know it!
column3: She loved him, too-she was sure she did-though she had never realized it before. Doubtless that was half the cause of her present restlessness and unhappiness-she had loved him all the time, and did not know it!

column2: Surely there was no one in the world who could so wisely help her in her dear work.
column3: Surely there was no one in the world who could so wisely help her in her dear work.

column2: Of course she loved him!
column3: Of course she loved him!

column2: Very softly Margaret crossed the room and touched the man's shoulder.
column3: Very softly Margaret crossed the room and touched the man's shoulder.

column2: Bobby, I did not understand--I did not know, she said gently.
column3: Bobby, I did not understand-I did not know, she said gently.

column2: You won't have to stay away--any more.
column3: You won't have to stay away-any more.

column2: Won't have to--stay--away!
column3: Won't have to-stay-away!

column2: The man was on his feet, incredulous wonder in his eyes.
column3: The man was on his feet, incredulous wonder in his eyes.

column2: No.	no
column3: true

column2: We--we will do it together--this work."
column3: We-we will do it together-this work."

column2: But you don't mean--you can't mean---- McGinnis paused, his breath suspended.
column3: But you don't mean-you can't mean---- McGinnis paused, his breath suspended.

column2: But I do, she answered, the quick red flying to her cheeks.
column3: But I do, she answered, the quick red flying to her cheeks.

column2: Then, half laughing, half crying, she faltered: "And--and I shouldn't think you'd make--_me_ ask--_you_!"
column3: Then, half laughing, half crying, she faltered: "And-and I shouldn't think you'd make-underscore me underscore ask-underscore you underscore!"

column2: Margaret! choked the man, as he fell on his knees and caught the girl's two hands to his lips.
column3: Margaret! choked the man, as he fell on his knees and caught the girl's two hands to his lips.

column2: [Illustration: "MARGARET CROSSED THE ROOM AND TOUCHED THE MAN'S SHOULDER."]
column3: [Illustration: "MARGARET CROSSED THE ROOM AND TOUCHED THE MAN'S SHOULDER."]

column2: CHAPTER XXXIII
column3: CHAPTER thirty three

column2: Ned Spencer returned alone to Hilcrest about the middle of April.
column3: Ned Spencer returned alone to Hilcrest about the middle of April.

column2: In spite of their able corps of managers, the Spencers did not often leave the mills for so long a time without the occasional presence of one or the other of the firm, though Ned frequently declared that the mills were like a clock that winds itself, so admirably adjusted was the intricate machinery of their management.
column3: In spite of their able corps of managers, the Spencers did not often leave the mills for so long a time without the occasional presence of one or the other of the firm, though Ned frequently declared that the mills were like a clock that winds itself, so admirably adjusted was the intricate machinery of their management.
